items.title: Visualizing algorithms
items.content:
#â€‹684 â€” April 18, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Quill 2.0: A Powerful Rich Text Editor for the Web â€” A major release and significant modernization for the open source WYSIWYG editor. In Announcing Quill 2.0, we learn about Quillâ€™s transition to TypeScript and improved use of modern browser features, but thereâ€™s more going on too, such as its ESM packaging. Want to play with some code? Thereâ€™s aÂ playground.

Slab Inc.

Airbnb's Extensive JavaScript Style Guide â€” Itâ€™s been years since we mentioned this popular, opinionated style guide, but it keeps getting little tweaks and repairs and remains a handy resourceÂ nonetheless.

Airbnb

WorkOS: Enterprise-Grade Auth for Modern SaaS Apps â€” WorkOS supports both the foundational auth and complex enterprise features like SSO. It provides flexible and easy-to-use APIs, helping companies like Vercel, Loom, and Webflow become Enterprise Ready. Best of all, WorkOS User Management supports up to 1 million MAUs forÂ free.

WorkOS sponsor

Upgrading jQuery: Working Towards a Healthy Web â€” jQuery remains all over the Web, and the jQuery team and OpenJS Foundation have joined forces to make sure sites get up to date. Their 'Healthy Web Checkup' tool can tell you if the version of jQuery on a site is outdated (.. most likely 'yes' ğŸ˜…).

Timmy Willison (jQuery)

Biome v1.7: Faster Formatting and Linting, Now Even Easier to MigrateÂ To â€” Biome is an increasingly compelling, all-in-one JavaScript, TypeScript and JSX Prettier-compatible formatter and linter. v1.7 makes it easier to migrate to from ESLint and Prettier, can emit machine-readable JSON reports, and has some ruleÂ updates.

Biome Core Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤¡ â–¶ï¸ Interview with Senior JS Developer 2024 is a satirical(?) take on the state of modern development and increasingly complex ecosystems. Watch to either laugh or cry. (6Â minutes.)

  • ğŸ“º Bartek Szwej has put together a list of 300 JavaScript-related videos from the past year, ordered by their YouTube viewÂ count.

  • f(x) (a.k.a. fx) is a great CLI tool for viewing JSON data. It now includes a JS engine so you can process JSON with JavaScript one-liners at the terminal,Â too.

  • Joyee Cheung shares a trip report from Node.js's latest collaboration summit, touching on the topics the Node team is thinking aboutÂ lately.

  • The folks at Deno go into depth about how they built JSR, the newest JavaScript registry, and how it can operate atÂ scale.

  • "Much faster JSX element creation" is on the way for ReactÂ developers.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Building a CLI from Scratch with TypeScript and oclif â€” oclif is a mature CLI tool development framework maintained by Salesforce. This tutorial goes from zero to something thatÂ works.

Josh Cunningham

Qwik vs. Next.js: Which is Right for Your Next Web Project? â€” A point by point faceoff between Qwik vs Next.js and why the author thinks Qwik takes theÂ goldÂ medal.

Samuel Mendenhall (Cisco)

RAG to Riches Developer Quest â€” Interact with AI-enhanced bots and learn to build your own RAG chatbot with Atlas Vector Search andÂ Node.js.

MongoDB sponsor

CSS in React Server Components â€” An exploration of compatibility issues between React Server Components and CSS-in-JS libraries likeÂ styled-components.

Josh W Comeau

Profiling Node.js Performance with Chrome's Performance Panel â€” Learn how to profile Node performance with Chrome's Performance panel. (The JS Profiler is going away in Chrome 124, so you'll need to become familiar with the newerÂ approach.)

Chrome for Developers

ğŸ“„ Keeping Up with the Node-ish Ecosystem â€“ How Mux updated its legacy Node SDK to work with new JSÂ runtimes. Dylan Jhaveri (Mux)

ğŸ“„ Building an Interactive 3D Event Badge with React Three Fiber Paul Henschel (Vercel)

ğŸ“„ A Deep Dive into Rspack and Webpack Tree Shaking hardfist

ğŸ“„ Things I Like Better in Vue Than in React Jaydev Mahadevan

ğŸ“„ Converting Plain Text To Encoded HTML With Vanilla JS Alexis Kypridemos

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

TresJS: Build 3D Experiences with Vue.js â€” Create 3D scenes with Vue components and Three.js. Think React-three-fiber but more.. Vue flavored. Thereâ€™s an online playground if you want to give it a quick spin (literally).

Alvaro Sabu

Next.js 14.2 Released â€” Approaching its eighth birthday, Next.js has passed 1 million monthly active developers and landed a release with support for using Turbopack to improve local development, memory usage, CSS and caching optimizations, improved error messages, andÂ more.

Delba de Oliveira and Tim Neutkens

Porkbun â€” The Best Domain Registrar for JavaScript Developers â€” JavaScript developers choose Porkbun to register their domains. Get .dev, .app, or .foo for just $5 from PorkbunÂ now.

Porkbun sponsor

Otto 0.4: A JavaScript Parser and Interpreter in Go â€” A JavaScript parser and interpreter written natively in Go (yes, we have a newsletter for that) which could be of interest if you want to add scripting to GoÂ apps.

Robert Krimen

Wedges: A Collection of UI Components for React â€” Built and used by the folks at Lemon Squeezy, this is a well thought, aesthetically pleasing set of Radix UI and Tailwind CSS based components. You can also download a Figma file of them to use when mocking up layouts. GitHubÂ repo.

Lemon Squeezy

HyperFormula: A Headless Spreadsheet System â€” A headless spreadsheet system â€“ it provides the parsing, evaluation and representation of a spreadsheet, with you providing the UI, if you need one. Boasts â€˜nearly full compatibilityâ€™ with Excel. Note the dual GPLv3 and commercialÂ licensing.

Handsoncode

svelte-dnd-action: An Action-Based Drag and Drop Container forÂ Svelte â€” Makes the bold claim that it â€œsupports almost every imaginable drag and drop use-case, any input device and is fullyÂ accessible.â€

Isaac Hagoel

âš™ï¸ Zoompinch: A Natural Feeling 'Pinch to Zoom' for Vue 3 â€“ Expected to come in React and Web Component variants inÂ time. Maurice Conrad

âš™ï¸ Craft.js â€“ A React framework for building drag and drop pageÂ editors. Prev Wong

âš™ï¸ Kotekan â€“ A simple React framework built on Bun and supporting React ServerÂ Components. Benedikt MÃ¼ller

âš™ï¸ Cytoscape.js 3.29 â€“ Graph theory/network visualization and analysisÂ library.

âš™ï¸ Tailwind Next.js Starter Blog 2.2 â€“ A blogging starterÂ template.

âš™ï¸ RxDB 15.18 â€“ Offline-first, reactive database for JSÂ apps.

âš™ï¸ JZZ 1.8.2 â€“ MIDI library for Node andÂ browsers.

âš™ï¸ Ember.js 5.8

â³Â A Blast from the Past

Visualizing Algorithms â€” This fantastic post is now ten years old, but I revisited it recently and itâ€™s such a joy. Mike Bostock (of D3.js fame) visually guides us through some algorithms using both demos andÂ code.

Mike Bostock

items.title: An easy way to experiment with signals
items.content:
#â€‹683 â€” April 11, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Frontend Development Beyond React: Svelte â€” A surprisingly thorough article going deep into one developerâ€™s research into using Svelte to build modern front-end apps. If youâ€™ve never experimented with Svelte, this is a good primer to the key concepts, tradeoffs, and techniquesÂ involved.

HÃ©la Ben Khalfallah

ğŸ› Â A JS Bin to Play with the TC39 Signals Proposal â€” Last week, we featured the proposal to add signals to JavaScript and by way of a polyfill, you can get experimenting with it rightÂ now.

NullVoxPopuli

Add Excel-Like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

zx v8.0: Write Better Shell Scripts with Node â€” A popular way to make shell scripting a more pleasant experience in Node with useful wrappers around child_process, argument escaping, and sensible defaults. v8.0 makes zx 20x smaller, faster, makes it easier to kill processes, pass input to commands &Â more.

Google

IN BRIEF:

  • Val Town is a fantastic online platform for writing and deploying TypeScript functions right from the browser and has just raised $5.5m in funding.

  • The set methods proposal advanced to stage 4 at TC39 this week. Promise.try and Math.sumPrecise have advanced to stage 2.7.

  • ğŸš— What happens if ğ• you hack a car with JavaScript?

  • Cloudflare has added a JS-native RPC to Cloudflare Workers.

  • A recap of Angular developments at the recent ngConf 2024 event.

RELEASES:

  • ESLint 9.0 â€“ A significant release with lots of cleanups, a new no-useless-assignment rule, and numerous tweaks andÂ changes.

  • VitePress 1.1 â€“ Vite & Vue-powered static siteÂ generator.

  • npm 10.5.2 â€“ It's now ğ• faster to run scripts, though we're talking millisecondsÂ nowadays.

  • Node.js April 10 Security Releases â€“ Including v18.20.2 (LTS), v20.12.1 (LTS), and v21.7.3 (Current).

  • We mentioned Gulp 5's release last week, but missed the announcing Gulp v5 post explaining why it's a bigÂ deal.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

On Developing Figma Plugins â€” Some interesting observations on the experience of creating Figma plugins in JavaScript, including how theyâ€™re sandboxed and some implementation details of the authorâ€™s ownÂ plugin.

Tom MacWright

React Server Components in a Nutshell â€” A quick overview of RSCs not all about Next.js, comparing the approach taken by several frameworks before sharing thoughts on the tech and why the smaller Waku framework is worth aÂ look.

Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

Using AI-Powered Autofix to Fix Your Broken Code â€” Join Sentry live on April 25th, to preview Autofix and learn how we are using ML to prioritize issuesÂ andÂ alerts.

Sentry sponsor

Some DevTools Tips and Tricks â€” Most developers barely scratch the surface of what DevTools can accomplish, says the author, who shares ten tipsÂ here.

Pankaj Parashar

ğŸ“„ Object Structure in JavaScript Engines â€“ You rarely need to know how objects are internally represented in JavaScript engines, but if you want to.. Frontend Almanac

ğŸ“„ The Easiest Way to Build Reactive Local-First Apps, with TinyBase and PowerSync Benedikt MÃ¼ller

ğŸ“„ Building an Article Recommendation System with Upstash, Fly and OpenAI Rishi Raj Jain

ğŸ“„ Browser Security Bugs That Arenâ€™t: JavaScript in PDFs ericlaw

ğŸ“„ Exploring Authentication in Next.js Robin Wieruch

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Madge 7.0: Create Graphs From Your Module Dependencies â€” A tool for generating a visual graph of module dependencies, finding circular dependencies, and discovering other usefulÂ info.

Patrik Henningsson

PythonMonkey: A JavaScript Engine in the Python VM â€” If you need to use Python but also want to run JavaScript, this gives you a way to do it with the Mozilla SpiderMonkey JS engine embedded into the Python runtime with Python providing the hostÂ environment.

Distributive

â¤ï¸ Loving console.log Is Easy, but Hate ğŸ˜¡ Losing Context to View Messy Output â€” Developer productivity tools Wallaby.js, Quokka.js and Console Ninja show console.log values and errors right next to yourÂ code.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Faces.js: A Library for Generating Vector-Based Cartoon Faces â€” The end results are somewhat reminiscent of how the Nintendo Wii generates random Miis. Faces are drawn as SVGs with each also represented by a JavaScript object so you can draw them againÂ later.

ZenGM

Color.js 0.5: 'Letâ€™s Get Serious About Color' â€” A fantastic library for working with colors in the browser, following the latest specs. Itâ€™s even been used by browsers to test their CSS Color 4/5Â implementations.

Lea Verou and Chris Lilley

Preview.js: Preview UI Components Instantly in Your IDE â€” Namely, VS Code or JetBrain IDEs, out of the box. Compatible with components built for React, Vue, Svelte andÂ Solid.

Zenc Labs Pty

Kosko: Organize Kubernetes Manifests in JavaScript â€” Version 4.1 has just been released with a new pluginÂ system.

Tommy Chen

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” "Compared to our previous experiences in the security/auth space, Userfront is an order of magnitude simplerÂ toÂ use."

Userfront sponsor

  • Mikro ORM 6.2 â€“ TypeScript ORM for Node.js based on Data Mapper. SQL Server and libSQL/Turso join the list of supportedÂ databases.

  • Rspack 0.6 â€“ Fast Rust-based webÂ bundler.

  • Pixi.js 8.1 â€“ The fast WebGL and WebGPU 2D graphics engine switches back to WebGL by default due to immature browserÂ support.

  • Jotai 2.8 â€“ Simple, flexible state management forÂ React.

  • DOMPurify 2.5 â€“ Fast, tolerant XSS sanitizer for HTML andÂ SVG.

  • Reveal.js 5.1 â€“ Framework for building presentations inÂ HTML.

  • Xterm.js 5.5 â€“ Create terminal experiences on theÂ Web.

  • TIFF 6.0 â€“ Pure JS TIFF imageÂ decoder.

  • Shiki 1.3 â€“ Powerful syntax highlighter.

ğŸ›Â It's wheely good..

Remember the iPod's click wheel? It's back. In JavaScript form!

items.title: A signal boost for JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹682 â€” April 4, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Proposal to Add Signals to JavaScript â€” A (very) early stage proposal for bringing a new feature to ECMAScript/JavaScript: signals! The proposal brings aboard ideas from a swathe of popular frameworks and aims to align everyone and get us on the same page when it comes to working with state and making updates based upon changes to state. Rob writes more about the proposalÂ here.

Rob Eisenberg and Daniel Ehrenberg

Build a RAG Chatbot App with MongoDB and Node.js â€” Embark on the RAG to Riches Developer Quest â€” a month of innovation, learning, and exclusive rewards awaits you. Youâ€™ll interact with AI-enhanced bots and learn how to build your own with Atlas Vector Search and Node.js. RegisterÂ now!

MongoDB sponsor

JS-Torch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript â€” Pythonâ€™s PyTorch is one of the gold standards amongst machine learning libraries, but this project brings some of its features directly into the JavaScript world. Hereâ€™s a live browser-based demo. Early days but this could become a bigÂ deal.

Eduardo Leao

Bun 1.1 Released: Now Supports Windows Too â€” With the lighthearted codename of Bundows, the alternative server side runtime now runs directly on Windows 10 and up (plus WSL, macOS and Linux, of course). This is a key step in its adoption, with even features like Bun Shell happy on Windows out of the box. Node compatibility continues to improve with support for node:http2 and IPC support between Bun and NodeÂ processes.

The Entire Bun Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Samuel GroÃŸ of the V8 team explains the V8 Sandbox, a security mechanism designed to prevent memory corruption in the V8 engine impacting other memory in theÂ process.

  • Dexie.js is a popular wrapper for IndexedDB and its creator has launched Dexie Cloud, a platform to store and synchronize data betweenÂ apps.

  • Svelte's Rich Harris is 'shaken up' after a misunderstanding around 'self-closing' HTML tags and their effect onÂ Svelte.

  • ğŸ¤¡ There was a curious JS-themed April Fools prank where a .js TLD for domain names was 'announced'. Sadly, it's not true, but there is js.org if you want something vaguelyÂ similar.

  • An official update on the merging of Angular andÂ Wiz.

RELEASES:

  • Deno 1.42 â€“ The alternative JS runtime adds first class support for JSR and improves Node.js compatibilityÂ further.

  • Babylon.js 7 (homepage) â€“ Key release of the popular rendering engine.

  • Node.js April 3 Security Releases â€“ Includes 18.20.1, 20.12.1 &Â 21.7.2.

  • Docusaurus 3.2 â€“ Popular content/docs siteÂ generator.

  • Gulp 5.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

What Even Is a JSON Number? â€” Despite the presence of standards around JSON, the answer is more complicated than youâ€™d think, particularly when it comes to interfacing with other ecosystems and languages that arenâ€™tÂ JavaScript.

Brian Terlson

The History of JS Interop in Dart â€” About twelve years ago, Google introduced Dart, a language which initially seemed set to take over a lot of JavaScriptâ€™s use cases, but which eventually found its own niche (notably with Flutter). JS interoperability has remained important, though, and with Dart 3.3 has gotten significantlyÂ better.

Sigmund Cherem (Google)

Everything I've Learned About Scaling Designs Systems (WithÂ Examples) â€” I've learned a lot about what it takes to build, maintain, and scale design systems initiatives at largeÂ companies.

StackBlitz sponsor

The BFCache Explained â€” The back/forward cache (â€˜bfcacheâ€™) is a browser optimization that makes going back and forward in the browser a faster experience â€“ itâ€™s been present for years and usually leaves you alone as a JavaScript developer, but there are things worth being awareÂ of.

Sabatino Masala

Running OCR Against PDFs and Images Directly in the Browser â€” A look behind the scenes at creating a simple tool using JavaScript to perform OCR against images and PDFs dragged on to theÂ page.

Simon Willison

The Easy Way to Access the Last Array Element
Ignace Maes

A Comparison of JavaScriptÂ CRDTs
Alexis MÃ©taireau

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Cally: Small, Feature-Rich Calendar Components â€” A collection of open-source calendar components for selecting single dates or date ranges. Framework-agnostic, themeable, localizable, and accessible (it even has an accessibility statement showing its commitment to thisÂ area).

Nick Williams

ğŸ“ŠÂ Counterscale: Scalable Web Analytics You Can Run on Cloudflare â€” A simple web analytics tracker and dashboard thatâ€™s designed to be easy to deploy and maintain by hosting it on Cloudflare (for free too, up to a certainÂ level).

Ben Vinegar

Product for Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your Product Muscle â€” Subscribe for free to get curated advice on building great products and best practices of topÂ startups.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸµÂ Tonal.js: A Music Theory Library â€” Packed with functions to manipulate tonal elements of music like notes, intervals, chords, scales, modes, and keys, and used as the basis of other music related projects. GitHubÂ repo.

danigb

Fancy-ANSI: Convert ANSI Text to HTML â€” If, for some reason, you want to convert text with ANSI escape codes into HTML.. Lots of examples on the homepage. GitHubÂ repo.

Andres Morey

Dioma: Dependency Injection Container for Vanilla JS and TS â€” No decorators, no annotations, no magic, no dependencies â€“ you just add the static scope property to your class and use inject to get anÂ instance.

Eugene Daragan

svelte-zoomable-circles: Svelte Component for Browsing HierarchicalÂ Data â€” A Svelte component for displaying and browsing hierarchical data using zoomable circles. LiveÂ demo.

Tyler Berbert

  • VineJS 2.0 â€“ Form data validation library for Node.js.

  • PGlite 0.1.1 â€“ Lightweight Postgres packaged as WASM into a TypeScript library for the browser, Node.js, Bun andÂ Deno. Now supports Postgres arrayÂ types.

  • TS-Pattern 5.1 â€“ Pattern matching library with smart typeÂ inference.

  • ical.js 2.0 â€“ Parser for ICS (RFC5545) and vCard (RFC6350)Â data.

  • Minimatch 9.0.4 â€“ Glob matching function â€“ used by npmÂ itself.

  • vue-tel-input 9.0 â€“ Telephone number input for Vue.Â (Demo.)

  • OverlayScrollbars 2.7 â€“ JS custom scrollbarÂ plugin.

  • Octokit.js 3.2 â€“ 'Batteries-included' GitHubÂ SDK.
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹682 â€” April 4, 2024


Read on the Web




    
    

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
A Proposal to Add Signals to JavaScript â€” A (very) early stage proposal for bringing a new feature to ECMAScript/JavaScript: signals! The proposal brings aboard ideas from a swathe of popular frameworks and aims to align everyone and get us on the same page when it comes to working with state and making updates based upon changes to state. Rob writes more about the proposalÂ here.
Rob Eisenberg and Daniel Ehrenberg 


  
  
Build a RAG Chatbot App with MongoDB and Node.js â€” Embark on the RAG to Riches Developer Quest â€” a month of innovation, learning, and exclusive rewards awaits you. Youâ€™ll interact with AI-enhanced bots and learn how to build your own with Atlas Vector Search and Node.js. RegisterÂ now!
MongoDB sponsor


  
  
JS-Torch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript â€” Pythonâ€™s PyTorch is one of the gold standards amongst machine learning libraries, but this project brings some of its features directly into the JavaScript world. Hereâ€™s a live browser-based demo. Early days but this could become a bigÂ deal.
Eduardo Leao 


  
  
Bun 1.1 Released: Now Supports Windows Too â€” With the lighthearted codename of Bundows, the alternative server side runtime now runs directly on Windows 10 and up (plus WSL, macOS and Linux, of course). This is a key step in its adoption, with even features like Bun Shell happy on Windows out of the box. items.title: Promises visualized
items.content:
#â€‹681 â€” March 28, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution â€” A helpful diagrammed and animated article, coupled with an (optional) 8-minute video, that goes into how promises work and are scheduled behind the scenes. Itâ€™s useful to have a good mental model of these mechanics, given promises form the basis of asynchronous functions inÂ JavaScript.

Lydia Hallie

â–¶Â Â Node.js: A Documentary of Its Origin Story â€” It's an hour long, but this documentary covers the history of Node particularly well, including how everything brewed up to the io.js fork of 2014. Easter weekend watching,Â perhaps?

Honeypot

Learn Advanced JavaScript Performance Optimization â€” Garbage collection, memory profiling, data structures like sets and arrays, and event loop management. Learn performance-driven programming, preparing you to write blazingly fast and efficientÂ code!

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • The Node.js Technical Steering Committee has confirmed there's no intention to remove npm from the main NodeÂ distribution.

  • Is Bun Windows Yet? No, but Bun 1.1, which will support Windows, is supposedly just four daysÂ away..

  • An example of a simple, yet useful, Web Component in a single GitHubÂ Gist.

  • The RedwoodJS framework now supports React Server Components too, as an alternative to its traditional GraphQL-basedÂ approach.

  • RunJS Play is a neat Web-based JavaScript playground that shows instant live feedback alongside eachÂ line.

  • Vercel now fully supports Node.js 20 for both builds and functions.

RELEASES:

  • VitePress 1.0 â€“ Powerful static siteÂ generator.

  • Neutralinojs 5.1 â€“ Alternative cross-platform desktop appÂ framework.

  • Babylon.js 7.0 â€“ Powerful game & 3D rendering engine. No official release post yet, but expected laterÂ today.

  • Radix Themes 3.0 â€“ Powerful frontend componentÂ library.

  • Node.js v20.12.0 (LTS) and Node v18.20.0 (LTS).

  • Deno 1.42.0, Vite 5.2, TypeChat 0.1, Chromatic 3.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

A Look at ECMAScript's Iterator Helper Methods â€” The proposal is several years old, but now at stage 3 in TC39, Iterator Helpers are being implemented and ship with V8 12.2/Chrome 122. The helpers are functions like .map, .filter, .take and .forEach and are made available to any object with Iterator.prototype in its prototypeÂ chain.

Rezvan Mahdavi Hezaveh (V8)

Introducing Waku's â€œPages Routerâ€ â€” Waku is an interesting minimal server-side React framework and itâ€™s now also bringing a minimal API to the modern React server components era: â€œMaking a Waku site is now as simple as making a few files and folders in the ./src/pagesÂ directoryâ€..

Sophia Andren

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” Userfront is an auth & identity platform that transforms your business to serve free, freemium and enterpriseÂ customers.

Userfront sponsor

What You Need to Know About Modern CSS â€” A guide with a list of the newest additions to CSS (think nesting, view transitions, :has(),Â etc). JS plays an occasional role too, whether by enhancing or polyfilling modern CSSÂ features.

Chris Coyier

Building a Micro HTMX SSR Framework â€” Matteo builds on an earlier tutorial about creating a â€˜movie quotesâ€™ app by exploring an alternative backend stack to use, based upon Fastify, Vite andÂ HTMX.

Matteo Collina

Meet Angularâ€™s New output() API â€” Outputs allow component authors to emit values to parent components.
Paul Gschwendtner (Google)

We Rewrote our React App in Svelte in Three Weeks
Dusty Phillips

How to Use the Web Bluetooth API
Confidence Okoghenun

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Trix 2.1: A Clean, Rich WYSIWYG Editor for the Web â€” A WYSIWYG editor developed by the folks at 37signals (known as the birthplace of Ruby on Rails). Itâ€™s used in their Basecamp and HEY apps, so is about as stress tested as you can get. GitHubÂ repo.

37signals

Meet the Future of Data Delivery with Hasura DDN â€” Join us April 16 for the unveiling of Hasura DDN. Create a unified, composable API, instantly and with noÂ maintenance.

Hasura sponsor

Atlassian's Pragmatic Drag and Drop Framework â€” A performance-focused drag-and-drop library that can be used to power experiences on any frontend stack. Thereâ€™s a live demo on the page along with a recording of a talk by Alex Reardon walking through the motivations for creating it and how itÂ works.

Atlassian

Create Vue3 App: A New Vue App Scaffolding Tool â€” Taking inspiration from tools like Create React App, this uses Vite to help you spin up a new Vue-based app using tools based upon answers you give to a number ofÂ questions.

Selemon Brahanu

<relative-time> 4.4: Format Timestamps as Localized RelativeÂ Times â€” Supply this web component with a standard formatted date and time and itâ€™ll render the right text toÂ suit. It's actually used all over GitHub itself (use Inspect Element on commit times).Â Demo.

GitHub

DOM3D.js: 3D DOM Viewer in a GitHub Gist â€” Some code you can copy and paste into your browser console to get a 3D view of the DOM, sort of.. (move your pointer to navigate the.. thing it creates). The effect is odd but fun to playÂ with.

Orion Reed

Free Auth for 1 Million MAUs â€” WorkOS provides easy-to-use APIs for authentication, user identity, and complex enterprise features like SSO andÂ SCIM.

WorkOS sponsor

  • PGlite 0.1 â€“ Lightweight Postgres packaged as WASM into a TypeScript library for the browser, Node.js, Bun and Deno.

  • npm-publish 3.1 â€“ GitHub Action to publish packages toÂ npm.

  • AdminJS 7.8 â€“ Automatic admin interface for Node.jsÂ apps.

  • Slonik 39.3 â€“ Node.js Postgres client with typeÂ safety.

  • react-three-fiber 8.16 â€“ React renderer forÂ Three.js.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
